title: Light
author: BrightBlocks42
pages:
Physics
Light is composed of
electromagnetic waves
with wavelengths
between 400 and 750
nm. This is the
spectrum humans can
actually perceive.  As
you decrease the
wavelength, light
becomes bluer,
reaching purple, and
as you increase the
wavelength, light

becomes redder. If
two objects are
moving away from
each other, they
appear redder to
each other, as the
wavelength is
stretched.  When we
discovered that most
galaxies appear
"red-shifted" to us,
we were able to
determine that the
universe is expanding

Etymology
The word "light" comes
from the Proto-
Germanic root
"leukhtam", which itself
came from the Proto-
Indo-European root
"leuk-", simply meaning
"brightness".  This
original root also
became multiple Latin
words, which gave
English words like
"illumination" and

"lunar".
Fun Fact: It appears
that Lucifer's name is
also derived from this
ancient root, with his
name originally
meaning "morning
star".




(etymonline.com)
